You must use the Rural Land Register (RLR) to register agricultural land.

You can register any type of land or property with HM Land Registry.

You must register your land with both the RLR and HM Land Registry to claim from most land-based funding schemes.

You only need to register land that you want to claim payments on, including land that you farm and qualifies for land-based payment schemes.

Either the landlord or the tenant can register land on the Rural Land Register, but the land can only be registered once.

However, it’s possible for the landlord to claim funds under one land scheme and their tenant to claim under another.

You can use the RLE1 form to register new land for the first time or make changes to land already on the Rural Land Register.

You’ll need to give your Single Business Identifier and enclose a map with a visible scale if you’re registering land for the first time or if your boundaries have changed.

Read the guidance on filling out form RLE1.

Answer: yes

You can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended.

‘Income losses’ are what you’d have got from giving driving lessons during the time you were suspended.

‘Non-income losses’ are other losses you can give a monetary value to, incurred (within reason) while you were suspended.

Examples of non-income losses include any reasonable costs you needed to pay to prepare your compensation application, the interest on a loan you had to take out as a result of the suspension, and the value of any damage that the suspension caused to your driving school business if you run one.

As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.

A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.

You’re allowed a reasonable amount of time off to deal with the emergency, but there’s no set amount of time as it depends on the situation.

Tell your employer as soon as possible how much time you’ll need so it can be agreed.

You could get time off when a dependant is involved in the following emergencies.

Illness, injury or assault

This includes mental or physical illnesses that don’t have to be life-threatening or need full-time care - it could be an existing condition that has worsened.

For example, if a dependant is mugged without being physically hurt, you could take time off to comfort or help them.

You can also take time off to arrange longer term care for a dependant.

If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone, this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

Contract terms can be in a written contract, verbally agreed, in an employee handbook, in an offer letter from the employer, required by law, in collective agreements, or implied terms.
